column4: how can i exclude a folder from a mv command? i want to do  mv ./* ./folder/  without trying to move folder into itself, so i need to exclude it
please read the mv man page (man mv).
it does not mention anything about exclusion
Right, there is none.  It will notice if you try to move it's self (.) and gripe that you can't do that.
huh? are you saying i cant do this?
Now what you can do is move files like this "mv * .??*" will move most everything but odd cases like .x, which are rare in Unix.
yes, but that assumes all my files are of the same extension, i have about 20 different file extensions in that folder
The man page is the final word, unless you use some other application (or write one).
no, my example has nothing to do with extensions, that is not really a valid concept in Unix.
you should read up on your shell (likely Bash) to see how it does wildcards as that is what folks use in Unix to choose groups of things.
what do you mean, "see how it does wildcards"?

Most shells in unix provide for "wildcards", magic characters that the shell expands into more then one file name, such as "less foo*" which will show you every file in this directory that begins with foo.
yeah, i know what wildcards are
the '*' is the wild card and is explained in the bash man page (if your using bash).
ls is not going to help me copy files is it?
No, but it will let you prototype the command that will, once you have the right files listed by doing ls WHATEVER, then you can do mv -t targetdir WHATWORKS.
